problem.tex: Let $f$ be an entire function and let $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$ with $|a|<R$ and $|b|<R$. If $\gamma(t)=Re^{it}, 0\leq t\leq2\pi$, evaluate \[\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{(z-a)(z-b)}dz.\] Use this result to give another proof of Liouville's Theorem.

solution.tex: First we rewrite the function $\frac{f(z)}{(z-a)(z-b)}$ as $f(z)(a-b)\left(\frac{1}{z-a}-\frac{1}{z-b}\right)$ to justify evaluating the integral(s) \[\int_\gamma f(z)(z-a)\left(\frac{1}{a-b}-\frac{1}{z-b}\right)dz=(a-b)\left(\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{z-a}dz-\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{z-b}dz\right).\] By Cauchy's integral formula these yield \[=(a-b)(f(a)-f(b)).\] On the other hand, an estimate gives \[\left|\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{(z-a)(z-b)}dz\right|\leq\int_\gamma\frac{|f(z)|}{|z-a||z-b|}|dz|.\] Suppose $f$ is globally bounded by $M$ in modulus. Then \[|(a-b)(f(a)-f(b))|\leq\int_\gamma\frac{M}{|z-a||z-b|}|dz|\] \[\leq\int_\gamma\frac{M}{(|z|-|a|)(|z|-|b|)}|dz|=\int_0^{2\pi}\frac{M}{(R-|a|)(R-|b|)}Rdt=\frac{2\pi RM}{(R-|a|)(R-|b|)}.\] Now for the proof structure. Let $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$ and suppose $R>|a|+|b|$. Then, by the above calculations, \[|f(a)-f(b)|\leq\frac{2\pi RM}{|a-b|(R-|a|)(R-|b|)}.\] Taking the limit as $R\to\infty$ (which we can do because $f$ is entire) shows $f(a)=f(b)$, which is only possible for all $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$ if $f$ is constant.
